content: Establishment of National Foreign Language Coordination Council. The "National Foreign Language Coordination Act of 2007" establishes the National Foreign Language Coordination Council within the Executive Office of the President, consisting of various government officials or their designees. The National Foreign Language Coordination Council, established by the "National Foreign Language Coordination Act of 2007," includes officials such as the Secretary of Commerce, Health and Human Services, Treasury, Housing and Urban Development, Agriculture, and the Chairman of the Export-Import Bank of the United States. Other heads of federal agencies may also be included. The Council is responsible for overseeing and implementing the National Security Language Initiative and developing a national foreign language strategy within 18 months. The National Foreign Language Coordination Council, established by the "National Foreign Language Coordination Act of 2007," is responsible for consulting with various stakeholders, conducting surveys on federal agency foreign language expertise, and monitoring strategy implementation through the application of laws. The National Foreign Language Coordination Council, established by the "National Foreign Language Coordination Act of 2007," is responsible for developing a strategy that includes recommendations for amending title 5 of the United States Code to enhance federal government recruitment and retention of individuals with foreign language proficiency. The strategy also addresses long-term goals of the National Security Language Initiative, crucial priorities across all sectors, and evaluation of federal foreign language programs and activities.
